transcript.text:
With regard to the question of common sense and 
freedom, there is a very rich tradition which

takes as its starting point the 
idea that people have natural rights

and that any institutional structure that 
infringes upon those rights is illegitimate.

And if it can be justified, it's only a sort 
of temporary, contingent justification under

particular circumstances. And one has to be 
questioning about such justifications. Now,

these intrinsic rights are held to be natural 
rights, that is a part of human nature. And

human nature as a part of the natural world... 
and if it's a part of the natural world we

ought to be able to learn about it by rational 
inquiry. And to some extent we can. But social

theory, and even more important, social practice, 
cannot be held in advance while science makes its

halting steps towards discovering the truth about 
human nature. And philosophy makes its perhaps

still more halting steps, towards exploring and 
clarifying the connection, which we all sense

exists, between rights and the nature in which 
they're rooted. A tricky and complicated question.

So, we have to make an intuitive leap as 
human beings, as moral agents. We have to

make an intuitive leap and establish a posit, 
and take a certain view and conception as to

what human nature is, and what rights grow 
out of it, and what structure of institutions

and interpersonal arrangements is legitimate 
with relation to what we take to be intrinsic

human needs and intrinsic human rights that 
grow from them. Now, any moral reasoning,

any decision with regard to a choice of 
action that's taken by a person of integrity,

a person who regards himself or herself as a 
moral agent, that is, considers their actions

to be judged by criteria of right or wrong, any 
such reasoning is based, implicitly at least,

on some conception of this sort. A moral act 
is undertaken, an act in the moral realm is

undertaken, at least in part, and maybe wholly, 
in terms of some consideration of the likely human

consequences and whether those human consequences 
will accord with human needs and human rights.

Now, some, say, religious pacifists might 
argue that that not all that's required

that use of violence is wrong, 
even if it happens to satisfy

and defend fundamental human needs and rights. 
One can question whether that's a moral stance

or an immoral stance. But, without going into 
those non-trivial issues, still it's true that

a large part, and maybe all of moral judgment is 
based on an assessment of the consequences, and

an evaluation of those consequences with regard to 
intrinsic human rights and intrinsic human needs,

and such an assessment can only be made on the 
basis of, at least, an implicit conception,

an implicit theory, if you like, of what human 
nature is. And a moral agent will undertake such

reasoning, a person who takes himself or herself 
seriously as a person of integrity will undertake

such reasoning to the extent that you can, and 
will also try to clarify the principles and the

grounding of the judgments as much as one can. 
That's what it means to be a moral human being,

whether you're dealing with your children, 
or foreign affairs, or whatever it is.

Now, there are a number of views about these 
topics that have been developed over the years,

but they are really intuitive judgments. They 
go well beyond the reach of scientific inquiry.

One conception is that a fundamental human 
need, and hence the fundamental human right,

is the right and the need to inquire and 
to create free of external compulsion.

That's in fact a leading doctrine of classical 
liberalism in its original 18th century version,

not the version that reaches us through, say, 
Margaret Thatcher, or something like that, but in

its original version. In fact, I was quoting from 
Wilhelm von Humboldt, who directly inspired John

Stuart Mill. And from this conception of human 
nature, that its fundamental basis is a need to

inquire and create free from any external 
compulsion, you derive certain consequences.

The consequence that Humboldt and his 
classical liberal followers derived

was that whatever does not springing from free 
choice, but only from instruction and guidance,

is alien to our nature. If a worker labors under 
compulsion or a student produces on demand,

as Humbult put it, we may admire 
what he does, but despise what he is.

Direction, guidance, and force, any kind 
of force, otherwise not. That's a certain

picture from that you can continue to spell out 
a conception of what the world ought to be like.

Well, I think, that's a rather attractive view, at 
least for the people of any faith in human worth

and dignity. And it does ground a certain social 
theory and certain choices of course of action.

Now, counterposed to that, there's a very 
different view, a view which in fact has been

dominant in modern intellectual discourse about 
these topics for the last several centuries. And

that's the doctrine sometimes called the 
empty organism theory: that people have

no intrinsic nature, that human nature is just 
the historical and cultural product, and that

the mind is a blank slate on which experience 
writes whatever it wants. And that the people

become whatever instruction and guidance makes 
them. That's a view which is familiar from modern,

though not classical, liberalism. It's explicit 
in Marx's theory where it takes a particular

form. And, in fact, it's the dominant conception 
of modern intellectual discourse on these matters.

And that view also has its consequences. 
One consequence is that there is no moral

barrier whatsoever to compulsion. 
Since there's no intrinsic human

nature and the human essence is just whatever 
experience, and culture, and history make it,

there's no barrier in the way of compulsion or 
shaping of behavior or manufacture of consent.

There's nothing that stands in the way of those 
who claim the right to coerce and control. And

notice that that's also an attractive view, namely 
from the point of view of those who undertake that

task and consider that their task, the task 
of control and coercion. And my own feeling

is that the reason for the prevalence of this 
doctrine, from what's called left to right,

is because it is so attractive. It's so attractive 
to the commissars, to the intellectuals, the

people who want the right to control and therefore 
want to eliminate the moral barriers to control.
Well, from that conception follows a different

notion of what are legitimate social institutions 
and legitimate courses of social action.

Well, apart from hopes and preferences, what can 
we learn about truth and falsehood? If we want to

discover which of these, or maybe some other view, 
is correct, we have to proceed by the methods of

inquiry that we undertake when we try to learn 
whether anything else is true or correct, again

whether it's in personal life or in scientific 
research. Not all that different. But now,

here we have to begin by refining and clarifying 
these notions and then subjecting them to direct

inquiry, experiment if possible, and so on. Now, 
that's actually been done in some areas, limited

areas, and it has some success, and there is some 
interesting results. One of the areas in which

it's been done is one of those that's mentioned 
in the introductory pamphlet or whatever it was,

the notification for this conference, where there 
was discussion of the notion of innate knowledge.

What Hume described as that part of our knowledge 
that comes to us from the original hand of nature,

what in modern terms, would be called that part of 
our knowledge that derives from genetic endowment.

Now, here there's a lot of work, and its general 
conclusion is that Hume vastly understated and

underestimated that part of our knowledge that 
comes to us from the original hand of nature.

And that a much more accurate perception was 
given by his predecessors, for example, the

English Platonists of the 17th century or 
Lord Herbert or the Continental rationalists

who assumed, and it turns out, as far as 
we know, rightly, that there's a very rich

structure of innate concepts and principles that 
lead to the growth of modes of perception, and

understanding, and interpretation, and judgment, 
and evaluation, and inquiry, and creation,

and so on. And that this is what leads to the 
possibility, to the human ability, to attain

rich and highly articulated and complex systems 
of understanding and thought, largely shared with

others and serving as the basis for everything 
from social interaction to personal discovery

and creation. Now, in any area where we know 
anything, this seems to be the conclusion. One

can still maintain the empty organism theory for 
areas where we don't know anything. You can say,

"well, maybe where we don't know anything, it's 
true," but that's not a very convincing position.

And I think that's, roughly speaking, a fair 
conclusion from present understanding. From

this point of view, it looks as though teaching 
is an irrelevance largely, and even learning is

sort of an artifact which happens only at the 
margins. And personal development and growth,

growth of the mind, is like growth of 
the body or, to be more precise, like

growth of other parts of the body since mental 
organs are just one species of physical organs.

That shouldn't be terribly surprising result. 
It shouldn't be too surprising to discover

that human beings above the neck are very much 
like human beings below the neck and, in fact,

like everything else in nature. But that would be 
the conclusion. That we know that that's true of

everything else in nature, of every other complex 
organism, and as far as we know, it's also true of

the mind, contrary to received doctrine of the 
sort that's dominated intellectual discourse.

Now again, I want to stress that these are only 
small areas. Most of the topics that interest

and concern us, actually nothing is known. 
Any layperson knows as much as the scientist

who's dedicated a lifetime of inquiry to these 
topics. But there are some small areas where

a lot is known, and this seems to be a kind of 
fair resume of the kind of thing that's known.

Well, where does that leave us with regard to 
social action and practice? The answer is very far

away. There still remains an enormous gap between 
what we have to grasp in order to ground moral

action, to choose a course of action on moral 
grounds. An enormous gap between that and what we,

in fact, understand about human nature 
and the human needs that derive from it,

and the human rights that derive from it. 
Big gap. So, we are left where we were,

with the need to make an intuitive leap and to 
posit some judgment about what real, intrinsic

human nature is. To try to evaluate and ground it 
as best we can. Always take a critical attitude

toward your assumptions and apply them where they 
can. But recognizing that there is, in a sense,

you're staking your faith in what you think 
or hope human beings may be. Now, if you

take as your faith that of, say, the classical 
liberal doctrine, you will conclude that there is

no justification, there's no moral justification 
for the commissar, the central committee,

or the cultural or corporate manager, or any 
of the others who control and coerce us on

species grounds. Notice that, 
from this point of view,

what is regarded as the progressive 
position, the one that's reflected in,

say, modern liberalism or Marxist thought 
and so on, is actually deeply conservative

and reactionary. It serves to legitimate existing 
institutions or other institutions of authority

and compulsion. In contrast, the actual classical 
liberal view, which is very different from what

is known with its deep innatist roots, is very 
subversive and radical because it challenges the

existence of any form of authority and requires 
that it be justified, which can rarely be done.

It's not too surprising, I think, that the 
actual ideas of the Enlightenment have been

subjected to such a broad-ranging attack. 
They are radical and subversive because

of the faith that they express in human 
capacity, and human rights, and human needs,

and their richness. And that's a deeply upsetting 
view from the point of view of any institutional

structure which is concerned with control and 
manipulation, or any of the people who operate

within those institutional structures. And, 
of course, those who do attain a position of

being articulate, where they can reach the 
public, well, they're the ones who in fact

satisfy the needs of the institutions. They're 
the ones who are called intellectuals. So,

it's not too surprising that these are the 
dominant views, the dominant articulated

views. There is constant resistance to them on 
the part of the general public, and I think it's

quite healthy and realistic. It's a resistance 
to infringement on fundamental human rights.

Well, if one takes this position, 
the next thing to do is to

make the intuitive leap and turn to the concrete 
substantive questions of acting as a moral agent,

choosing a course of action. And here what 
you do is seek out structures of authority and

domination. Often we don't see them, so you have 
to try to find them even though they're there.

Once you notice them, you see them and seek them 
out. Ask the question as to whether they, in fact,

are legitimate for some contingent reason, 
say, self-defense or whatever argument is put

forth. And if they fail that test, as they almost 
invariably do, to move forward to dismantle them,

which means solidarity, organization, and 
so on. That's a hard task. You can look

back at history and gain a certain degree of 
encouragement from it. But you'll also learn

from history that there's a lot of suffering 
that goes on in acting like a moral agent.

Suffering and satisfaction, both. But there 
are achievements. There are real achievements.

For most of human history, for example, literal 
human slavery was considered legitimate. In fact,

considered quite praiseworthy. It was for 
the benefit of these depraved creatures

who shouldn't be left on their own. It's only a 
little tiny period of human history where this

is considered a total obscenity. And the fact 
that it is considered a total obscenity is an

achievement. In the 18th century, it was pointed 
out that wage slavery is fundamentally not very

different from slavery. If people are compelled 
to rent themselves in order to survive, it's not

very different than selling yourself in order 
to survive. That's an insight that has yet to

be recovered, but it's a valid one. And, in fact, 
notice that it grows from these same conceptions

of human nature. But, at least, literal human 
slavery would no longer be justified by,

I suppose, almost anyone. Maybe Roger 
Scruton or someone, but almost no one.

That's an achievement. It's a moral 
achievement. It's a moral advance.

Just in our own lifetimes, the questions of the 
legitimacy of sexist oppression have come to the

fore. It's not like anybody noticed before, 
but there's been a sustained and committed

effort to bring them to consciousness. And 
it's not long ago, anybody my age will know,

that it's not long ago they just didn't 
see it, notice it. It was just part of

the background. Now, at least you see it. The 
problems are there, but it's a moral advance

that the problems are recognized to be there. 
There's some effort to come to terms with them.

And the same is true in every other domain. Take, 
say, freedom of speech, which is in many ways the

fundamental human freedom. You don't have 
freedom of speech, you don't have anything

else. The battle for freedom of speech has been 
a long and bitter one and it's very far from

won. In this respect, the United States is maybe 
the most advanced country. At least there is a

structural guarantees for freedom of speech 
of the sort that don't exist anywhere else,

as far as I know. But that's very recent, and 
it's worth bearing in mind that it's very recent.

Theoretically, freedom of speech is established 
by the First Amendment to the Constitution,

but that's pure theory. It never meant a thing. 
The freedom of speech barely existed throughout

most of American history, long after the Bill of 
Rights. In fact, that was understood at the time.

James Madison, one of the major authors, pointed 
out that what he called a parchment barrier will

never stand in the way of tyranny. Rights are 
not gained by writing down words on paper,

but by constant struggle to achieve them, to 
discover what they are, and to secure them, and

to defend them. And there has been a long struggle 
in the United States. The labor movement, and the

anti-war movement, and the civil rights movement, 
and other popular movements finally expanded the

domains of freedom of speech to the point where 
they reached effect by 1969. In the Supreme Court,

they finally reached the libertarian standard 
that had been declared by people like, say,

Jeremy Bentham in 1776. And I think the 
United States is alone in this respect. Now,

that's typical. All of human history is a history 
of… everything that's decent in human society,

that I can think of, derives from unremitting 
and constant popular struggle to identify

human nature and its characteristics, to 
determine the rights that follow from it,

and to fight for those rights. 
It's not an easy task. If there's

another way to achieve it than constant 
struggle, it has yet to be made public.
